transcript.content: The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Hello. Welcome to another podcast of the Ricky Gervais show with me, Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant.
Hello.
All right? And, of course -- Karl Pilkington.
Alright..?

Rick, you'll be pleased to know we've already had some responses. You remember last week I mentioned that you can email us on podcast@rickygervais.com if you've got anything for Karl or you or I. And Simon and Mark have already emailed us in this link to something that was on the BBC News website. I don't know if you're familiar with this, but it's a remarkable story. Steve: Em.. Well, I'll just  -- I'll give you the headline straight away and you can. You can draw your own conclusion: "Lion Mutilates 42 Midgets in Cambodian Ring Fight". That's just the headline.
That's a hell of a headline. That makes me want to know more about that story.
Yes, that's what a headline..
..that's what a headline should do.
I mean, I think we'd all read the news -- we'd all take more interest in the news if they could open the, you know, BBC News at six o'clock every night..
BONG!
.. bong! "Lion Mutilates 42 Midgets in Cambodian Ring Fight."
BONG!
Bong! We'd definitely pay more attention. So this is the story, it's just extraordinary: "Spectators cheered as entire Cambodian Midget Fighting League squared off against African lion."
Now I didn't even know there was a Cambodian Midget Fighting League.
You're an ignoramus.
Unbelievable..
Everyone, of course, has heard of the CMFL, which is genuinely what it's known as Cambodia.
Brilliant.
Now, like you, I don't know who the Cambodian Midget Fighting League are normally fighting. I don't know what tournaments they..
I assume it's each other.
Well, I assume each other.
It's midget fighting then.
Yeah. Well, let me just give you more information and then we'll.. we can dissect it afterwards.

(Reading from the article) "Tickets had been sold out three weeks before the much anticipated fight. The fight was organized when an angry fan contested Yang Shimoni, president of the CMFL, claiming that one lion could defeat his entire league of 42 fighters."
So this bloke is going to the president and going: "I reckon a lion could get all your midgets"..

"I reckon he could.." yeah "He could destroy all of your 42 midget fighters." Now apparently Shimoni, the president of the CMFL, he takes great pride in the league and he's conveyed in a recent advertising campaign that his midgets will take on anything: man, beast or machine. Now I don't know what kind of machine, again, midgets are fighting..
But don't the midgets have a saying in this?
..a washing machine.
And the midget's going: "all right, keep it down".
(Laughs)
(As the manager) "They will fight anything..." (As the midget fighter) "Well, we won't fight anything; we'll fight each other. We're sort of, like, equally matched."
(As the manager) "No, you'll fight a beast or a machine."
(As the midget fighter) "No, no, no, no no!"
.. "I'll fight another midget. I will fight any midget, is what -- When I said I'll take on anything, I meant another midget!"
..machines.
So this bloke goes: "I reckon the lion could take on your midgets." He goes: "rubbish."

Yes, and that is why an African Lion was shipped in especially for the event which took place a couple of Saturdays ago in the city's coliseum. I mean, they've already got -- they've got a coliseum, Rick, which is already brilliant.
So hold on. This is sanctioned by the city.

(reading from the article) "The Cambodian Government allowed the fight to take place under the condition that they receive a 50% commission on each ticket sold and that no cameras would be allowed in the arena".
(laughs) I love the fact "we'll take 50%. But, you know, for dignity's sake" (laughs) "there's no cameras".
(laughs) That's amazing!
"We don't want to make this into a -- you know - into a spectacle.
No, no, it's just- it's just lion versus midget. But, you know.
Well, 42. Never forget there was 42 midgets. Now this is- this is the tragedy element and this is why we shouldn't be laughing, because the fight was ended.
Don't tell me the lion gets hurt.
Well, the fight was ended, Rick, after only twelve minutes, after which 28 of the midget fighters were declared dead.
Right.
While the other 14 suffered severe injuries, including broken bones, lost limbs, and they were basically unable to fight.
But the lion wasn't hurt.
It would have seemed that the lion was okay.
Oh, good. Because the lion had no choice in this.
No.
See, that's the- the- I-I-I love it when a human takes on a beast and comes unstuck because that lion was scared and defending itself. Those little midgets were loving it. They wanted to go.
What do you mean they were loving it? You don't know that!
Well, why would they do it?

Well, what I find odd- Well, I worried, you see, I don't know the ins and outs of this. I wonder if they were fighting against their will. I got the horrible feeling because with all due respect to any midgets listening, they must be fairly easy to round up. You could probably corral some midgets fairly easily, you know. You generally need some regular full sized people and it'd be easy to grab some widgets and take that away, whisk them away, put them in a cage.
No, because. No, no, no. Because they don't. Because a lot of them stand on each other's shoulders and wear a long coat
Sure, but-
And a hat. And you go, oh, that's not a midget.
Well, those ones are getting away with it. They're fine. They're wandering around, you know, fine, because who's voluntarily going to join the Cambodian Midget Fighting League?

But midgets who want a bit of action, who want to fight other midgets, they're allowed. They want to fight. They can't get in real boxing matches because the fellas are too big for them. But they can go "Well, I'll tell you what. Let's have our own little fighting league," right?

But if I was on the Cambodian Midget Fighting League, I'd be livid. I'd be thinking to myself, well, I can't believe I listened to my agent and he's put me up fighting a lion. I mean, I should have just taken panto in Grimsby. I can't believe what I've done
I can't believe it. But hold on, though. I thought, are they all really midgets or are they lumping in dwarves with them?
It's not specified, Rick, but uh-
That annoys me when people say, "Oh, look at these midgets." And I go, "Hold on though, they're making up the numbers with a couple of dwarves there. That's clearly only 39 midgets and three dwarfs!"
Sure.
Well, that's amazing.
Karl, what are your thoughts instantly? I mean, you're going to have a take on that.
Whose side am I meant to be on there?
What?

Well, I'd be on the lion side if I, I'd never go to a bullfight. But I love it when I see a matador gored to death. Because again, the bull doesn't want to get in that ring and fight a bloke with swords. Okay? So I love it. I think it's disgusting. And when someone says midget versus lion, I'm thinking, well, it's okay if the lion wins, to be honest, because they haven't got a choice. So. And I hate it when people go, "I went to a bullfight when I was in Spain, but it's the tradition, isn't it?" Oh, well, there's loads of traditions that we don't adhere to anymore, so I'm glad, you know, I say it shouldn't have happened, of course, but if it happens, I'm glad the lion isn't hurt.
See, what's annoying me is I've sent money to Cambodia because apparently they're hungry and haven't got any energy. So what's going on?
Well, it's. It's much easier to fill up a midget than it is a regular Cambodian, you know, they're just happy on a Mars bar
Hmm... I just feel like I'm being cheated a bit.
You were conned before with a charity, weren't you?
Well, a few times, yeah.
Well, what about the old lady? What was that?

I got stopped. And it's like they sort of drag you in by saying, have you got a gran? And I said, no, they died. And that. It's like, oh, did they die in the cold? No, she's, you know, ill. What have you, just old age. He said, well, what happens with a lot of people's grans is they die in the cold, right? So I was like, oh, that's bad, isn't it? Anyway, so she's chatting and she's showing me pictures of these old women who look cold, right? Saying, look at her. That's Edna, you know, she's got no family, she can't pay the bills and all that. So, yeah, anyway, it goes on for about 15 minutes and you feel bad, you give them your bank details, right? And what happens is every couple of months you get a letter from Edna. It's not from it, it's typed up and what have you. But. But there's a picture of Edna, right? And it's saying, oh, this December, you know, Edna's gonna be extra cold. It's cold outside. She can't afford to pay the heat and what have you. Yeah, keep going, right? So you keep paying every month, like five pounds, whatever, get another letter a few months later, right? Edna sat there. She's got a tan.
What do you mean she's got a tan?
Well, when they said, you know, she's cold, I thought they meant for the heating, not to send her on holiday for a month. She sat there with a tan? I'm not joking.
Are you sure it wasn't just a sort of a slight problem in the printing?
No, no. Definitely sure it wasn't. Well happy.
Sure it wasn't liver failure.
This is terrible thing to say, but when I see those people approaching now with the clipboards on the street, I always get my mobile phone out and.
Pretend I'm a conversation.
The number of fake conversations I've had walking past them now, well, I felt.

Sorry for them because I thought, you know, to me fair, I've got about ten standing orders where I felt sorry for my court, right? I thought, they're doing a good deed that he. So I could do. I find out they're on about eight quid an hour.
Are they? Yeah, they're not just doing it at the kindness of their heart.
Well, I don't want to.
Volunteers. I thought that was at least why I should feel guilty if they're getting paid to do it.
I don't know. That could be wrong.
I think they do what I've heard to get. They get paid in that.
Well, if someone knows, maybe podcast at.
Ricky Gervais.com is how you can get in touch with us. Because if, you know, if these guys are getting fleeting us twice, you know.
I heard something Karl thinks you think they're not.
I don't know anything, but I know anything that will allow me to.
But let's find out because, you know, I don't want to, I don't want to slag him off because they're obviously doing a good thing. So we find this out. You know, this is an educational show.

I'll tell you what though, right? Because we've talked about homeless people before and that, and I walked past one the other day, he's always cheerful, right? But don't you think, right, if you had a company, it's worth taking them on because they never have a lie in.
Brilliant.

I'm finding it quite exhausting now because a lot of the homeless I've encountered recently, they don't even now they're not even after my money. They're just, they're just looking for conversation. While I was walking along the other day, and I don't know what you're supposed to say to this, we were both walking, happened to be both passing a chinese restaurant. He glanced in, he looked, he looked back around me. He went, woman in there with three phones. Three mobile phones. Why does she need three mobile phones? Got nothing to say to that. Got no opinion. Got absolutely no opinion of it. And I was thinking, what's going, you know, and you know that thing when you sort of suddenly got across the road conveniently to just get out of it, but, and there's another mad woman who started going. She was walking past me. She went, do you want to come to my church? I went, no, I don't believe in God. She went, do you believe God? Oh, 20 minutes conversation, 20 minutes. It was unbelievable. I got to a point where I was so angry with her. I was shouting out from across the other side of the room. I was the one who sounded like a nutter. Going, there isn't a God, you see.

When does it become like, bad to avoid people like that? Do you know what I mean? Because some people say you shouldn't. You know, they're people, they're people like us who just had a bit of bad luck.
Of course they are.

Yeah, I know, but I remember one on our estate, right. And she was a bit, what's, what's the word that you can use? Because I don't want to offend anyone, but I'd say men, men. Yeah, but sort of mental homeless. Is that a term?
That's the official term.
I think that is-
That is the new official term. It's, it's mental-homeless-itis.
Right. So she, she lived on the estate and what have you. And she aged pretty-
How was she homeless if she lived on the estate?
Well, she sort of decided to stay around there 'cause I think people on the estate spoke to her more than people who had money. Do you know what I mean?
Really? I was gonna say, why would they, why would she choose an estate to, not to live in as opposed to, like, a walled sort of lovely community?
Yeah.
Why not go to St. John's Wood or-
Yeah, I'd hang around in, maybe, say, the maze in Hampton Court.
Yeah, exactly, yeah.
No one's expecting to see a homeless person as they're trying to find their way around that. Imagine the cash you'd make during the summer.
The rich sort of Victorians used to keep sort of homeless in their, as a little folly. And they used to pay them at the end if they stayed there for, like, three years.
What do you mean? They would pay them for what?
It was fashionable to have a little, like a little homeless little hobbit in your, in your outhouse. Seriously!
And what did they have, did they have to do anything for the money? Run, dance, fight tigers?
No, they just had to be there. No, they had to be there when they brought around. They'd go, "Look, that's our, that's our little Catweazel fella living in our folly."
Yeah.
And then they were. They got money, you know, at the end of it, there's just like, really rich sort of Victorians and stuff.

That's a great idea. They should definitely bring that back because, you see, I would give a lot more to Shelter and those kind of charities if I could have a homeless guy come round and do my bidding. I could make him dance.
And they have a really long beard.
Yeah.
And rags.
Exactly.
Yeah.
And they could, I could just make them do dances for me or, you know.
And he was somewhat magical, possibly. He'd go "Riddle me dee, fiddle me do. What is my name? And who are you?"
Yeah, exactly.
And then. Yeah, yeah.
Anyway, so this mental homeless-
There's a little idea for Shelter, if anyone's listening.

Mental homeless woman on the estate and what she used to do, she acted quite normal and she used to always push, like a pram around with her, right? Everyone was like, she can't have a kid, can she? Right? And she was dead happy. Every day she was up and down, walking up and down the road. Anyway, one day she sort of walked past, right? Turned round and looked in the pram. There's a bucket with a face on it.
The Ricky Gervais Show on Guardian Unlimited.
Rick, we've had an email here from a bloke. I think you're gonna respect him because I think you can tell straight away from his name that he's the kind of guy you'd want to hang out with.
Go on.
I know how much you love fun people.
Yeah.
Well, Paul, and he's calling himself this. Paul "The Party Animal" Parker, he's emailed in. He's giving himself that moniker.

They're in speech marks, yeah. Paul "The Party Animal" Parker.
Brilliant. And he's calling himself that.
Yeah,
That. I can't wait.
When you picture him, what you thinking?
Milhouse. I think he looks like Mill House from the Simpsons.

Yeah possibly. Oh, I think he might still be at school.
Okay right, yeah.
Ricky laughs
This is the vital question. Do you believe him to be a party animal?
I believe him to be a party animal in as much as a man with a long scarf that his Mum knitted him to look like Doctor Who can be a party animal. Yes.
Do you think that when people are organising parties at his school, they're thinking the first person they got to on the list and make sure he's guaranteed as a guest
You got to take Paul the party, because I bet he's got millions of affectations. I bet he wants to be known as the one that carries around a biscuit tin.
Yeah.
You know, he's got the scarf.
He's the guy who only ever wears bowling shoes.
Ricky laughs

It's his thing. He's a little bit kooky, it's his thing. Thank you very much indeed for your contribution. And it is fairly interesting what he sent in. He's found this on the web. I don't know why he's felt an affinity with this, with this particular inventor, but anyway, there's a man, a Serbian man, who has invented a sex machine for women, and he's appealing to Western women to test his device. He's from a town in, as I say, in Serbia, I guess. Serbia, I guess. That's right. Is that right?
Well, I don't know. What does it say?
Well, it says a Serbian man. Is it called Serbia? Yeah.
Yeah.
What was all the Croatia Serbia thing?
It doesn't matter now, does it?
Okay, "it doesn't matter now." It does to them! Otherwise, they fought for nothing. What the hell do we know about world events? I mean, how long did that go on for? Months, wasn't it?
If they're inventing new countries, they can't expect me to keep up with current trends, can we?

Anyway, this Serbian man has. Has invented a sex machine for women, and he can't find any Serbian women to try it out. So he's looking now for Western women. He's taken out the patent on the ultimate sex machine. It runs on a 390 volts electric engine, simulates sex, and has a seven and a half inch artificial penis. He said, "My sex machine has an artificial penis that can make up to 180 moves in a minute." Now, I don't even know what that means, 180 moves. What? I mean there's only really-
Well, in and out, I imagine
In and out, is largely the function... unless I've been doing it wrong all these months
What he's, what he's done is he's, he's put a dildo on a black and decker.

A man can only manage the intensity of movement for about 5 seconds normally. But this machine can do it for as long as the woman wants. But anyway, so he's looking for a woman who will test this out. But what I love, as soon as I read this, I was thinking it's just imagine him there going, "Oh, thanks for coming in. Yeah. There's a lot of dials and stuff. I don't wanna bore you with..."
Why do you have to stand behind it? Just...
I can't, it's technical stuff, but I gotta be behind the machine.
But there's no, there's no penis on the robot at the moment, just a hole.
Don't worry. What'll happen is I'll switch the machine on, I'll go behind, and then a penis will appear.
Will it be like a metal looking penis?
It will be a robotic penis, but it will seem like it's a regular fleshy human penis.
So you're gonna say, all right, so you're gonna go behind this robot.
Go behind them and disappear.
Yeah.
And then a fleshy looking penis is gonna appear through the hole-
When I switch the machine on.
Okay and that'll be the real robotic penis-
But you won't see me for the duration of your sexual encounter.
So you've, you've made this sort of like, robotic penis, this look really realistic.
It's really realistic. You will not be able to tell the difference between, say, the robot one and mine, for instance.
Okay, well, I don't want to see yours.
No, no, no, absolutely not.
I've not come round here to have sex with a person.

I know, you've come round to test the machine, and that is exactly what you're going to get. Without the use of mechanical action. But what I like is the idea that on the front, maybe he's painted a picture of a robot's face.
Yeah.

And then when the machine begins, you know, rather like in one of those horror houses, like a kind of mansion in a spooky film, the eyes of the painting, they'll move and the real eyes will appear just staring out. Well, I don't think I can have sex with this machine unless you're actually in the room, just in case any goes wrong. Don't worry, I'll be behind the machine, it'll be fine, it'll be safe. Not a problem. But anyway, so, yeah, Paul The Party Animal Parker, sent that in. And knowing him, there'll be plenty more coming like that in future weeks.
Karl, what do you think about that? The uh-
Machines and that?
Yeah.
Well they've always been, sort of. I mean, to a lot of people, sex is important, innit? You know what I mean?
Not to you?
Well, it serves a purpose.
What purpose?
No, no-
'Cause you don't want to have kids, so what purpose?
Just, you know.
Something to do.
Something to do in the evening.
When the telly's broke.
But, but for years, like, they've found stuff, haven't they? Machines from like Roman times, that-
No. No machines in Roman times.
Like that though. The old sort of a knob on a stick machine thing.
The old Roman knob on a stick! I'm sorry, but I watch Time Team every week, and Tony Robinson has never done that, an old knob on a stick machine.
I just think that Julius Caesar sitting down and go, okay, aqueduct, we love that. Thanks for that. Straight roads, good idea. We can see the enemy coming. What have you got there?
Well, I'm glad you've asked.
Plonkticus. What have you got there, Wanklicus?
What I've got here is a ye olde knob, and I've put that on the end of a stick.
Oh, a stickus phallus? Okay, well done, Wanklicus, well done. You are my new right hand man, as they say. Excellent.
But they do, they do stuff like that. You've been in the London Museum and that, and they've got sort of sex stuff from years ago. They've got like these metal pants that they used to wear.
I don't know what that is!
Little pants?
Yes, that they used to wear.
Is that a chastity belt? You mean, they used to make women wear them so that they could have sex when-
They had them for blokes as well, though.
Metal pants for blokes? Why?
So if they, if he was away, he couldn't, he couldn't play away from home, and if he was away, she popped on a little-
No, I just think they sort of like sexy metal pants.
Well, I don't know what you mean. These sexy metal pants.
Well, we'll have to look because I haven't got it in front of me. It's just something I remember seeing, some sort of sexy metal pants that they used to wear.
But what are you saying? Sexy metal pants?
Karl, that was not the British museum, that was Soho.
No, what I mean is-
That was Old Compton Street. You were looking in the shop window.
They always had to be ready for, like, battle and that. But these were a little bit sexy, but protective at the same time.
I love that! I love that!
That's all you remember from Sir Lancelot.
Are you ready to face the Black Knight? Yeah. What do you think of these? Huh? What do you think of these? Well, I don't really care. Just, you know, I just want to.
Look good on the battlefield.
Well, they're both protective.
Will there be women watching, cheering us on?
Well, you're not gonna fight like that, are you? What about you?
I'm gonna wear nothing except these sexy metal pants.
But you, what about your chest is exposed?
Nah, it's a good chest. I'll be working out.
Yeah, I know, but what I mean is, you want to, you want you metal.
I've actually been lifting up the round table every week. I just work out, do that about four times a day.
But that machine, right? Why did it have to be a woman? Or could they have got a little gay fella in?
I just check.
Doesn't actually specify the small print here.
I love that. Why do you want to see a little gay fella be?
I don't know. I don't want to see it. I'm just saying they're sort of more.
Carl, why do you want to see, why do you want to watch a gay man get buggered by a robot?
I wasn't the one typing in gay machines on the Internet, finding stuff out.
About, it's not a gay machine. You just made it into a game machine.

Yeah, he wanted it. He wanted to pleasure women with this machine. You're saying, can I see a little gay fellow get a robotic cock up his ass? You're the one requesting that car. I'm just saying, you're the one that want to see gay men with metal stuff up there are.
No, what I'm saying is they're more up for a bit more experimentation than.
What are you saying? Why is that the case?
Why? Why'd you say that?
No, just, just, you know, butt plugs and that. I mean, what I'm saying is you.

I'm just saying that they. I reckon they'd be up for it.
What do you know about butt plugs?
Well, I don't know anything about them. I just remember seeing an advert for someone in a sex shop. I wasn't. I was just walking past. I was walking past the sex shop and that.
Hmm.
And you're always looking, why were you.
Walking past a sex shop?

Just because I was on the way to work and that. And I passed one and there was a little sort of one. It was open early, which I never understood. Right. It was about 08:00 in the morning. Right, who needs them now, right?
I must get a bagel and some poppers on the way to work.

I walked past it and, like a little post it note or postcard type thing, and it was like, pop in now. Buy an item. Chucking some free butt plugs. And I didn't know what they thought. Another email here. This is. They haven't let them give their name, actually, but they. It's an interesting fact. I'm hoping it's true. I can't be doing with that.
You hate nudist, don't you?

I don't know. I don't understand the question.
What's your point?

Well, you know, are there any blokes who are knocking about who just have a normal sized knob or maybe a bit smaller than normal and who are happy wandering about showing off what. What they haven't got, if, you know.
I mean, I don't think nudists are just doing it because they're so proud of their knob.
No, but there's got to be a little bit of that in it. And they say, like, you know, Jonathan Ross, right? He's. He's nipped to see you now and again, what have you.
He's what?
He sort of nipped in to see you now and again. He's always happy getting his knob out because he's known to have this big knob. Right? What do you mean he's known.
Why is Jonathan Ross known to have this big knob?
No, he just talks about a lot, don't he? He's always saying about, oh, you know, but you'd like this, wouldn't you?
Like me? I'm known for being a great lover. I say it a lot. It's clearly not the case. What evidence have you got that he's got a bigger.

No, but the difference is he's happy to keep getting it out. It's different sort of me walking about going, ah, I've got a bigger and all that and then. But no one ever sees it. But Jonathan sort of. He's. He's always getting it out.
Have you seen him get out before?
I saw. Well, he did get out, but I wasn't. I wasn't looking.
What do you mean you weren't looking? How do you know it was out?

Just because he sort of was moving it about and that, and I could sort of see. No, I wasn't looking, though. It was that is that sort of thing where you can see something moving about. I'm not looking at it.
What, like an owl seeing a. Seeing a mouse?
Like what?
I mean, it doesn't matter. All I'm saying is. So.
No, let's get back to see you. You remembering vividly Jonathan Ross's penis.
No, I don't mean that.
But why were you looking at his penis looking, though, when it was clearly not meant to be looked?
I'm just saying most blokes who, you know, nudists, they must be pretty confident in themselves to, you know, getting it out and I wasn't looking. It's just that, I mean, I looked once.
Okay, what was it like?
What, sorry, you looked at Jonathan's once.
No, no, I was looking at another one.
What are you looking at? Loads of men's penises.
Where are you?
It's natural. That's what I'm saying.

No.
A lot of guys are getting changed.
You're at your bedroom window with a pair of binoculars and there's a little fella across the road.
Night out once.
Go on.
So you were at heaven and you were in. In the toilet.

At his genitals or his two heads? Or would you sneak. You look at the heads and then think, I wonder if he's got two cocks and just.

I'd have to have a look there. I'll tell you what. And now I admit it, if I'm ever in a gym and a naked man with two heads walks in, I probably will check out the genitals as well, just to make sure that he's got two of everything.

Can I tell you the thing that always freaks me out? I do sometimes go to the gym and I live in north London. And the thing that always freaks me out is if there's an elderly man, often quite short, and I don't. I say this only so you can picture something in your. In your mind's eye, you know, because I live in northern. There's quite a lot of elderly jewish gentlemen wandering around. And I'm always freaked out because there's at least two I'm aware of who've got very, very large penises. And I always find that really disturbing because sometimes you can't, you know, you can't help but notice because it's like Godzilla coming through the changing room. Do you know what I mean? It's swinging there. And it never seems right that he's an old guy, you know, he's kind of a little overweight, quite short, and he's got a massive piece of action going on between his legs. And I always get, dare I say it, a little bit jealous because for a tall man, I feel I've been a little bit short changed.
Oh, wow.
So that -- I do admit that's the only instance where my eye has been naturally drawn to it.
Do you know what annoys me in gyms? Where people walk around happily naked all the time, whistling. They get weighed naked. Pop a towel on and take off 3 ounces.

Do you know what I mean -- pop a towel on? I mean..

Couple of stone. Yeah, a couple of ounces.
Exactly..
Yeah. Yeah. Absolutely right, Well, we've.. we've put that to bed.
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.

Well, no, because they're different species. They're all primates, but..

But the thing is, you know, I mean, in a way -- this is linked to the one in the salon. He could cut hair, but you'd never be allowed to work on the till.. Right? But these tests that they've been doing. They're..

So..

You could never teach a monkey the value of money.
So the thing is, they've said to these monkeys, look, you know, there's your money..
They haven't said anything..
..to the monkeys
You're only getting so much money
The have, Rick -- please, listen to the news!
(laughs) That is the news (laughs)
It's the news.
It's important that, you know, they know how to spend that money, right?
(laughs)
It's basic rules, really. It's for what you teach a human about money isn't it -- it's what you teach kids.
So invest wisely.
Invest and all that.
Sorry, who's teaching these monkeys..
So they give these mon..
Sorry, Karl, stop.
Just some people and that.
But who..But where are these monkeys?
Where have these monkeys been..
I think it's in San Francisco.

..where are these monkeys, though? What are they.. are they in a shop? Are they, what are they doing? Are they in homes? What are they doing?

Probably just in like some sort of science place where science people are checking out monkeys brains and that and seeing how they work. But they're happy. They're not cutting them and that.
Cutting and that..
This is different to the.. news at ten.
So listen..

trivia.description:
This was a well-distributed hoax article from 2 May 2005. Although this was purported to be from the BBC, it was actually provided on someone's personal website in the style of the BBC, stating the event was to take place in Kâmpóng Chhnãng, the capital of Cambodia. (Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20050609031635/https://lionvs40midgets.uk-directory.com/).
It also appeared in the Lads mag Maxim and shock-jock Howard Stern's show.
The person who wrote it wanted to settle a bet with his friend and ended up writing a fake article to convince his friend who was certain the 40 midgets would win in the hypothetical fight, using a previous article from the BBC about Cambodian "zombies" as the template.
The author wrote it as a joke, but it quickly ended up becoming a viral sensation due to it being posted to sites like FARK and CollegeHumor, and forwarded via email to many people around the world, including, apparently, Steve Merchant and Ricky Gervais. Snopes wrote an article explaining the background here: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/lion-in-wait/
Ready, Steady Cook was a BBC cookery show starring chef Ainsley Harriot and other chefs, who were given a bag of ingredients and were asked to make dishes, usually on a budget.

![Ricky dons his only suede jacket to receive the award](https://web.archive.org/web/20070809010826if_/http://www.positive-internet.com/news/release-photo.jpg)
The first season of the podcast according to Positive Internet had 261,670 downloads a week, which led to The Ricky Gervais Show podcast being included in the 2006 Guinness Book of World Records. When interviewed in February 2006 Ricky said: "Steve and Karl wanted to charge for the podcast. Just a pound they said. I said no. We've had nearly 3 million downloads so far. It's difficult doing a show with two people who won't talk to me now."
